10870Journal of Chemical CrystallographyJ Chem Crystallogr1074-15421572-8854Springer USBostons10870-012-0283-z28310.1007/s10870-012-0283-zOriginal PaperSynthesis and Crystal Structures of Polymeric Copper(II) Complexes Derived from Tridentate Schiff BasesLinXue-Song1aSangYa-Li1XiaoWen-Min1grid.443353.6Department of Chemistry and Chemical EngineeringChifeng University024000ChifengPeople’s Republic of Chinaxuesong_lin@126.com212201262012426578582722012171120117220122122012© Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 20122012Abstract

A new end-to-end thiocyanato-bridged 1D polymeric copper(II) complex [CuL1(μ1,3-NCS)]n (1), and a new end-on azido-bridged dimeric copper(II) complex [CuBrL2(μ1,1-N3)]2 (2), where L1 is the deprotonated form of 2-[1-(2-methylaminoethylimino)ethyl]phenol (HL1) and L2 is N-methyl-N′-(1-pyridin-2-ylethylidene)ethane-1,2-diamine, have been synthesized and structurally characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectra, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n with unit cell dimensions a = 10.822(1) Å, b = 10.054(1) Å, c = 12.532(2) Å, β = 106.810(2)°, V = 1305.3(3) Å3, Z = 4, R1 = 0.0341 and wR2 = 0.0766. Complex 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n with unit cell dimensions a = 10.427(2) Å, b = 10.672(2) Å, c = 12.626(2) Å, β = 108.069(9)°, V = 1335.7(4) Å3, Z = 2, R1 = 0.0346 and wR2 = 0.0714. The Cu atom in 1 is in a square pyramidal coordination, and that in 2 is in an octahedral coordination. The Cu···Cu distances are 6.406(1) Å in 1, and 3.762(1) Å in 2. The pseudohalide anions are versatile bridging groups for the construction of polymeric structures of Schiff base copper(II) complexes.

Graphical Abstract

Two new polymeric copper(II) complexes derived from tridentate Schiff bases have been synthesized and characterized.

Schiff bases are readily synthesized by the condensation reaction of carbonyl-containing compounds with primary amines [1, 2]. In recent years enormous amount of work on polymeric copper(II) complexes with Schiff bases has been reported due to their interesting structures and wide applications [3–5]. The azide and thiocyanate anions can bind two or more metal ions in the μ1,1-, μ1,3-, μ1,1,1-, μ1,1,3-, and many other modes, yielding various one-, two-, and three-dimensional species [6–10]. The versatile features of metal-azido and metal-thiocyanato systems in coordination chemistry may lead to novel structures that are difficult to obtain with other bridging ligands, but a major obstacle is impossible to predict which coordination modes will be adopted by the azide and thiocyanate ligands. During the search of literature, we found that the copper(II) complexes derived from the tridentate Schiff base ligands 2-[1-(2-dimethylaminoethylimino)ethyl]phenol and N,N-dimethyl-N′-(1-pyridin-2-ylethylidene)ethane-1,2-diamine have been extensively studied [11–15], however, no complexes have been reported for the similar tridentate Schiff base ligands 2-[1-(2-methylaminoethylimino)ethyl]phenol (HL1; Scheme 1) and N-methyl-N′-(1-pyridin-2-ylethylidene)ethane-1,2-diamine (L2; Scheme 1). In continuation of the work on the azide and thiocyanate-bridged complexes with Schiff bases, a new end-to-end thiocyanato-bridged 1D polymeric copper(II) complex [CuL1(μ1,3-NCS)]n (1), and a new end-on azido-bridged dimeric copper(II) complex [CuBrL2(μ1,1-N3)]2 (2), were synthesized and structurally characterized.

ExperimentalMaterials and Measurements

2-Acetylphenol, 2-acetylpyridine, and N-methylethane-1,2-diamine with AR grade were obtained from Aldrich and were used as received. Elemental analyses were performed using a Perkin–Elmer 240C analytical instrument. Infrared spectra were recorded on a Nicolet 5DX FT-IR spectrophotometer with KBr pellets. The Schiff bases were prepared according to the literature method [16].

Synthesis of [CuL<sup>1</sup>(<italic>μ</italic><sub>1,3</sub>-NCS)]<sub><italic>n</italic></sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

To a stirring methanolic solution (10 mL) containing copper(II) bromide (44.6 mg, 0.2 mmol) was added dropwise a methanolic solution (10 mL) of HL1 (38.4 mg, 0.2 mmol). Then a solution of ammonium thiocyanate (15.2 mg, 0.2 mmol) dissolved in 5 mL water was added to the reaction mixture. The stirring was continued for half an hour and filtered. The filtrate was kept undisturbed at room temperature for a week. Deep blue crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained on slow evaporation of the solvent. Crystals were isolated by filtration and dried in air. Yield 63% with respect to the HL1. Analysis calculated for C12H15CuN3OS: C, 46.1; H, 4.8; N, 13.4%; found: C, 46.3; H, 4.9; N, 13.3%.

Synthesis of [CuBrL<sup>2</sup>(<italic>μ</italic><sub>1,1</sub>-N<sub>3</sub>)]<sub>2</sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

To a stirring methanolic solution (10 mL) containing copper(II) bromide (44.6 mg, 0.2 mmol) was added dropwise a methanolic solution (10 mL) of L2 (35.4 mg, 0.2 mmol). Then a solution of sodium azide (13.0 mg, 0.2 mmol) dissolved in 5 mL water was added to the reaction mixture. The stirring was continued for half an hour and filtered. The filtrate was kept undisturbed at room temperature for a week. Deep blue crystals of 2 suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained on slow evaporation of the solvent. Crystals were isolated by filtration and dried in air. Yield 51% with respect to the L2. Analysis calculated for C20H30Br2Cu2N12: C, 33.1; H, 4.2; N, 23.2%; found: C, 33.0; H, 4.2; N, 23.4%.

X-ray Crystallography

Suitable single crystals with high quality of complexes 1 and 2 were selected and mounted on a Bruker Smart 1000 CCD area-detector diffractometer with graphite monochromatized Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Diffraction data for both complexes were collected by ω scan mode at 298(2) K. Data reduction and cell refinement were performed by the SMART and SAINT programs [17]. Empirical absorption correction was applied by using SADABS [18]. The structures of the complexes were solved by direct methods and refined with the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXL97 package [19]. The non-H atoms in the structures were subjected to refined anisotropic refinement. The amino hydrogen atoms in the complexes were located from difference Fourier maps and refined isotropically, with N–H distances restrained to 0.90(1) Å. The remaining hydrogen atoms were located in geometrically and treated with the riding mode. Crystallographic data and experimental details for the complexes are summarized in Table 1. Selected bond lengths and angles for the complexes are listed in Table 2. Hydrogen bonds are summarized in Table 3.

Results and DiscussionCrystal Structure Description of <bold>1</bold>

The molecular structure of the complex 1 is shown in Fig. 1. The complex is an end-to-end thiocyanato-bridged polymeric copper(II) compound, with the Cu···Cu distance of 6.406(1) Å. The asymmetric unit of the complex is [CuL1(NCS)]. The Cu atom is five-coordinated in a square pyramidal coordination. The basal plane of the square pyramid is defined by the phenolate O, imine N and amine N atoms of L1, and one thiocyanate N atom. The apical position of the square pyramid is occupied by one thiocyanate S atom. The Cu1–O1 bond length of 1.879(2) Å in the complex is a little shorter than those [1.91–1.98 Å] reported in similar copper complexes with Schiff bases [16, 20, 21]. The Cu–N bond lengths [1.968(2)–2.014(2) Å] in the complex are comparable to those [1.91–2.05 Å] reported in the copper complexes [16, 20, 21]. The substantial distortion of the square pyramid is revealed by the bond angles between the apical and basal donor atoms, which show deviation from the ideal 90° angle in a regular square pyramid. Atom Cu1 displaced out of the least-squares plane defined by the four basal donor atoms in the direction of the apical position by 0.167(2) Å. The thiocyanate ligands are nearly linear and show bent coordination mode with the Cu atoms (N3–C12–S1/Cu1–N3–C12/Cu1A–S1–C12 = 179.0(3)°/158.2(2)°/116.1(1)°).

In the crystal structure of 1, the [CuL1] units are linked through end-to-end thiocyanate bridges, forming chains running along the b axis (Fig. 2). The chains are further linked via intermolecular N–H···S hydrogen bonds in the c direction, forming layers parallel to the bc plane.

Crystal Structure Description of <bold>2</bold>

The molecular structure of the complex 2 is shown in Fig. 3. The complex is an end-on azido-bridged centrosymmetric dimeric copper(II) compound, with the Cu···Cu distance of 3.762(1) Å. The inversion center of the complex is located at the midpoint of the two Cu atoms. The Cu atom is six-coordinated in an octahedral coordination. The equatorial plane of the octahedral geometry is defined by the pyridine N, imine N and amine N atoms of L2, and one azide N atom. The axial positions of the octahedral geometry are occupied by one Br atom and one azide N atom. The Cu1–N1 bond length of 2.036(3) Å in the complex is a little longer than those [1.97–2.02 Å] reported in similar copper complexes with Schiff bases [22, 23]. The remaining Cu–N bond lengths [1.976(3)–2.045(4) Å] in the complex are comparable to those [1.92–2.06 Å] reported in the copper complexes [16, 22, 23]. The substantial distortion of the octahedral coordination is revealed by the coordinate bond angles, which show deviation from the ideal values in a regular octahedral geometry. The axial Cu–Br and Cu–N bonds are much longer than those in the equatorial plane, which is caused by the Jahn–Teller distortion. Atom Cu1 displaced out of the least-squares plane defined by the four equatorial donor atoms in the direction of the Br atom by 0.276(2) Å. The azide ligands are nearly linear and show bent coordination mode with the Cu atoms (N4–N5–N6/Cu1–N4–N5 = 176.2(5)°/132.2(3)°).

In the crystal structure of 2, there forms two intermolecular N–H···N hydrogen bonds between the two symmetry-related [CuL2] units (Fig. 4). There are no obvious short contacts among the dimeric molecules.

IR Spectra

The weak and broad band centered at 3,412 cm−1 is due to the stretching vibration of the phenolic OH group of HL1. The band is absent in the spectrum of 1 indicating the coordination of the phenolate oxygen atom of the ligand to the Cu atom. The middle and sharp bands indicative of the NH groups are located in the region 3,165–3,230 cm−1 for the Schiff bases and the complexes. The phenolic ν(C–O) in the spectrum of HL1 was observed as strong band at 1,202 cm−1. However, in the spectrum of 1, the band appeared at 1,232 cm−1. This confirms the deprotonation and coordination of the phenolate oxygen atom to the Cu atom. The strong bands at 1,605–1,615 cm−1 in the spectra of the free Schiff bases are due to the azomethine groups, which are shifted toward lower frequencies (1,598 cm−1 for 1 and 1,597 cm−1 for 2), indicating the coordination of azomethine nitrogen atoms to the Cu atoms. The intense band for 1 at 2,097 cm−1 is the typical vibration of the thiocyanate ligands, and that in 2 at 2,053 cm−1 is the typical vibration of the azide ligands. The weak bands in the region 340–600 cm−1 for the complexes are attributed to the Cu–N, Cu–O, Cu–S, and Cu–Br vibrations.

Conclusions

A new end-to-end thiocyanato-bridged 1D polymeric copper(II) complex and a new end-on azido-bridged dimeric copper(II) complex have been synthesized and structurally characterized. The Schiff base 2-[1-(2-methylaminoethylimino)ethyl]phenol coordinates to the Cu atom through the phenolate O, imine N, and amine N atoms. The Schiff base N-methyl-N′-(1-pyridin-2-ylethylidene)ethane-1,2-diamine coordinates to the Cu atom through the pyridine N, imine N, and amine N atoms. The pseudohalide anions are versatile bridging groups for the construction of polymeric structures of Schiff base copper(II) complexes.

The remaining Cu-N bond lengths [1.976(3)-2.045(4) Å] in the complex are comparable to those [1.92-2.06 Å] reported in the copper complexes [16, 22, 23]. The substantial distortion of the octahedral coordination is revealed by the coordinate bond angles, which show deviation from the ideal values in a regular octahedral geometry. The axial Cu-Br and Cu-N bonds are much longer than those in the equatorial plane, which is caused by the Jahn-Teller distortion. Atom Cu1 displaced out of the least-squares plane defined by the four equatorial donor atoms in the direction of the Br atom by 0.276(2) Å. The azide ligands are nearly linear and show bent coordination mode with the Cu atoms (N4-N5-N6/Cu1-N4-N5 = 176.2(5)°/132.2(3)°).In the crystal structure of 2, there forms two intermolecular N-H⋅⋅⋅N hydrogen bonds between the two symmetry-related [CuL2] units (Fig. 4). There are no obvious short contacts among the dimeric molecules.IR SpectraThe weak and broad band centered at 3,412 cm-1 is due to the stretching vibration of the phenolic OH group of HL1. The band is absent in the spectrum of 1 indicating the coordination of the phenolate oxygen atom of the ligand to the Cu atom. The middle and sharp bands indicative of the NH groups are located in the region 3,165-3,230 cm-1 for the Schiff bases and the complexes. The phenolic ν(C-O) in the spectrum of HL1 was observed as strong band at 1,202 cm-1. However, in the spectrum of 1, the band appeared at 1,232 cm-1. This confirms the deprotonation and coordination of the phenolate oxygen atom to the Cu atom. The strong bands at 1,605-1,615 cm-1 in the spectra of the free Schiff bases are due to the azomethine groups, which are shifted toward lower frequencies (1,598 cm-1 for 1 and 1,597 cm-1 for 2), indicating the coordination of azomethine nitrogen atoms to the Cu atoms. The intense band for 1 at 2,097 cm-1 is the typical vibration of the thiocyanate ligands, and that in 2 at 2,053 cm-1 is the typical vibration of the azide ligands. The weak bands in the region 340-600 cm-1 for the complexes are attributed to the Cu-N, Cu-O, Cu-S, and Cu-Br vibrations.ConclusionsA new end-to-end thiocyanato-bridged 1D polymeric copper(II) complex and a new end-on azido-bridged dimeric copper(II) complex have been synthesized and structurally characterized. The Schiff base 2-[1-(2-methylaminoethylimino)ethyl]phenol coordinates to the Cu atom through the phenolate O, imine N, and amine N atoms. The Schiff base N-methyl-N'-(1-pyridin-2-ylethylidene)ethane-1,2-diamine coordinates to the Cu atom through the pyridine N, imine N, and amine N atoms. The pseudohalide anions are versatile bridging groups for the construction of polymeric structures of Schiff base copper(II) complexes.Supplementary MaterialCCDC reference numbers 854102 for 1 and 854103 for 2 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. elements.content: A new end-to-end thiocyanato-bridged 1D polymeric copper(II) complex [CuL1(μ1,3-NCS)]n (1), and a new end-on azido-bridged dimeric copper(II) complex [CuBrL2(μ1,1-N3)]2 (2), where L1 is the deprotonated form of 2-[1-(2-methylaminoethylimino)ethyl]phenol (HL1) and L2 is N-methyl-N′-(1-pyridin-2-ylethylidene)ethane-1,2-diamine, have been synthesized and structurally characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectra, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n with unit cell dimensions a = 10.822(1) Å, b = 10.054(1) Å, c = 12.532(2) Å, β = 106.810(2)°, V = 1305.3(3) Å3, Z = 4, R1 = 0.0341 and wR2 = 0.0766. Complex 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n with unit cell dimensions a = 10.427(2) Å, b = 10.672(2) Å, c = 12.626(2) Å, β = 108.069(9)°, V = 1335.7(4) Å3, Z = 2, R1 = 0.0346 and wR2 = 0.0714. The Cu atom in 1 is in a square pyramidal coordination, and that in 2 is in an octahedral coordination. The Cu···Cu distances are 6.406(1) Å in 1, and 3.762(1) Å in 2. The pseudohalide anions are versatile bridging groups for the construction of polymeric structures of Schiff base copper(II) complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A new end-to-end thiocyanato-bridged 1D polymeric copper(II) complex [CuL1(μ1,3-NCS)]n (1), and a new end-on azido-bridged dimeric copper(II) complex [CuBrL2(μ1,1-N3)]2 (2), where L1 is the deprotonated form of 2-[1-(2-methylaminoethylimino)ethyl]phenol (HL1) and L2 is N-methyl-N'-(1-pyridin-2-ylethylidene)ethane-1,2-diamine, have been synthesized and structurally characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectra, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n with unit cell dimensions a = 10.822(1) Å, b = 10.054(1) Å, c = 12.532(2) Å, β = 106.810(2)°, V = 1305.3(3) Å3, Z = 4, R1 = 0.0341 and wR2 = 0.0766. Complex 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n with unit cell dimensions a = 10.427(2) Å, b = 10.672(2) Å, c = 12.626(2) Å, β = 108.069(9)°, V = 1335.7(4) Å3, Z = 2, R1 = 0.0346 and wR2 = 0.0714. The Cu atom in 1 is in a square pyramidal coordination, and that in 2 is in an octahedral coordination. The Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances are 6.406(1) Å in 1, and 3.762(1) Å in 2. The pseudohalide anions are versatile bridging groups for the construction of polymeric structures of Schiff base copper(II) complexes.

elements.content:
Two new polymeric copper(II) complexes derived from tridentate Schiff bases have been synthesized and characterized.

Introduction

Schiff bases are readily synthesized by the condensation reaction of carbonyl-containing compounds with primary amines [1, 2]. In recent years enormous amount of work on polymeric copper(II) complexes with Schiff bases has been reported due to their interesting structures and wide applications [3–5]. The azide and thiocyanate anions can bind two or more metal ions in the μ1,1-, μ1,3-, μ1,1,1-, μ1,1,3-, and many other modes, yielding various one-, two-, and three-dimensional species [6–10]. The versatile features of metal-azido and metal-thiocyanato systems in coordination chemistry may lead to novel structures that are difficult to obtain with other bridging ligands, but a major obstacle is impossible to predict which coordination modes will be adopted by the azide and thiocyanate ligands. During the search of literature, we found that the copper(II) complexes derived from the tridentate Schiff base ligands 2-[1-(2-dimethylaminoethylimino)ethyl]phenol and N,N-dimethyl-N′-(1-pyridin-2-ylethylidene)ethane-1,2-diamine have been extensively studied [11–15], however, no complexes have been reported for the similar tridentate Schiff base ligands 2-[1-(2-methylaminoethylimino)ethyl]phenol (HL1; Scheme 1) and N-methyl-N′-(1-pyridin-2-ylethylidene)ethane-1,2-diamine (L2; Scheme 1). In continuation of the work on the azide and thiocyanate-bridged complexes with Schiff bases, a new end-to-end thiocyanato-bridged 1D polymeric copper(II) complex [CuL1(μ1,3-NCS)]n (1), and a new end-on azido-bridged dimeric copper(II) complex [CuBrL2(μ1,1-N3)]2 (2), were synthesized and structurally characterized.

Graphical Abstract

Two new polymeric copper(II) complexes derived from tridentate Schiff bases have been synthesized and characterized.

Introduction

Schiff bases are readily synthesized by the condensation reaction of carbonyl-containing compounds with primary amines [1, 2]. In recent years enormous amount of work on polymeric copper(II) complexes with Schiff bases has been reported due to their interesting structures and wide applications [3-5]. The azide and thiocyanate anions can bind two or more metal ions in the μ1,1-, μ1,3-, μ1,1,1-, μ1,1,3-, and many other modes, yielding various one-, two-, and three-dimensional species [6-10]. The versatile features of metal-azido and metal-thiocyanato systems in coordination chemistry may lead to novel structures that are difficult to obtain with other bridging ligands, but a major obstacle is impossible to predict which coordination modes will be adopted by the azide and thiocyanate ligands. During the search of literature, we found that the copper(II) complexes derived from the tridentate Schiff base ligands 2-[1-(2-dimethylaminoethylimino)ethyl]phenol and N,N-dimethyl-N'-(1-pyridin-2-ylethylidene)ethane-1,2-diamine have been extensively studied [11-15], however, no complexes have been reported for the similar tridentate Schiff base ligands 2-[1-(2-methylaminoethylimino)ethyl]phenol (HL1; Scheme 1) and N-methyl-N'-(1-pyridin-2-ylethylidene)ethane-1,2-diamine (L2; Scheme 1). In continuation of the work on the azide and thiocyanate-bridged complexes with Schiff bases, a new end-to-end thiocyanato-bridged 1D polymeric copper(II) complex [CuL1(μ1,3-NCS)]n (1), and a new end-on azido-bridged dimeric copper(II) complex [CuBrL2(μ1,1-N3)]2 (2), were synthesized and structurally characterized.

elements.content: Ligands HL1 and L2

2-Acetylphenol, 2-acetylpyridine, and N-methylethane-1,2-diamine with AR grade were obtained from Aldrich and were used as received. Elemental analyses were performed using a Perkin–Elmer 240C analytical instrument. Infrared spectra were recorded on a Nicolet 5DX FT-IR spectrophotometer with KBr pellets. The Schiff bases were prepared according to the literature method [16].

Experimental

Materials and Measurements

2-Acetylphenol, 2-acetylpyridine, and N-methylethane-1,2-diamine with AR grade were obtained from Aldrich and were used as received. Elemental analyses were performed using a Perkin-Elmer 240C analytical instrument. Infrared spectra were recorded on a Nicolet 5DX FT-IR spectrophotometer with KBr pellets. The Schiff bases were prepared according to the literature method [16].

elements.content: To a stirring methanolic solution (10 mL) containing copper(II) bromide (44.6 mg, 0.2 mmol) was added dropwise a methanolic solution (10 mL) of HL1 (38.4 mg, 0.2 mmol). Then a solution of ammonium thiocyanate (15.2 mg, 0.2 mmol) dissolved in 5 mL water was added to the reaction mixture. The stirring was continued for half an hour and filtered. The filtrate was kept undisturbed at room temperature for a week. Deep blue crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained on slow evaporation of the solvent. Crystals were isolated by filtration and dried in air. Yield 63% with respect to the HL1. Analysis calculated for C12H15CuN3OS: C, 46.1; H, 4.8; N, 13.4%; found: C, 46.3; H, 4.9; N, 13.3%.

Synthesis of [CuL1(μ1,3-NCS)]n (1)

To a stirring methanolic solution (10 mL) containing copper(II) bromide (44.6 mg, 0.2 mmol) was added dropwise a methanolic solution (10 mL) of HL1 (38.4 mg, 0.2 mmol). Then a solution of ammonium thiocyanate (15.2 mg, 0.2 mmol) dissolved in 5 mL water was added to the reaction mixture. The stirring was continued for half an hour and filtered. The filtrate was kept undisturbed at room temperature for a week. Deep blue crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained on slow evaporation of the solvent. Crystals were isolated by filtration and dried in air. Yield 63% with respect to the HL1. Analysis calculated for C12H15CuN3OS: C, 46.1; H, 4.8; N, 13.4%; found: C, 46.3; H, 4.9; N, 13.3%.

elements.content: To a stirring methanolic solution (10 mL) containing copper(II) bromide (44.6 mg, 0.2 mmol) was added dropwise a methanolic solution (10 mL) of L2 (35.4 mg, 0.2 mmol). Then a solution of sodium azide (13.0 mg, 0.2 mmol) dissolved in 5 mL water was added to the reaction mixture. The stirring was continued for half an hour and filtered. The filtrate was kept undisturbed at room temperature for a week. Deep blue crystals of 2 suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained on slow evaporation of the solvent. Crystals were isolated by filtration and dried in air. Yield 51% with respect to the L2. Analysis calculated for C20H30Br2Cu2N12: C, 33.1; H, 4.2; N, 23.2%; found: C, 33.0; H, 4.2; N, 23.4%.

Synthesis of [CuBrL2(μ1,1-N3)]2 (2)

To a stirring methanolic solution (10 mL) containing copper(II) bromide (44.6 mg, 0.2 mmol) was added dropwise a methanolic solution (10 mL) of L2 (35.4 mg, 0.2 mmol). Then a solution of sodium azide (13.0 mg, 0.2 mmol) dissolved in 5 mL water was added to the reaction mixture. The stirring was continued for half an hour and filtered. The filtrate was kept undisturbed at room temperature for a week. Deep blue crystals of 2 suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained on slow evaporation of the solvent. Crystals were isolated by filtration and dried in air. Yield 51% with respect to the L2. Analysis calculated for C20H30Br2Cu2N12: C, 33.1; H, 4.2; N, 23.2%; found: C, 33.0; H, 4.2; N, 23.4%.

elements.content: Suitable single crystals with high quality of complexes 1 and 2 were selected and mounted on a Bruker Smart 1000 CCD area-detector diffractometer with graphite monochromatized Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Diffraction data for both complexes were collected by ω scan mode at 298(2) K. Data reduction and cell refinement were performed by the SMART and SAINT programs [17]. Empirical absorption correction was applied by using SADABS [18]. The structures of the complexes were solved by direct methods and refined with the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXL97 package [19]. The non-H atoms in the structures were subjected to refined anisotropic refinement. The amino hydrogen atoms in the complexes were located from difference Fourier maps and refined isotropically, with N–H distances restrained to 0.90(1) Å. The remaining hydrogen atoms were located in geometrically and treated with the riding mode. Crystallographic data and experimental details for the complexes are summarized in Table 1. Selected bond lengths and angles for the complexes are listed in Table 2. Hydrogen bonds are summarized in Table 3.

X-ray Crystallography

Suitable single crystals with high quality of complexes 1 and 2 were selected and mounted on a Bruker Smart 1000 CCD area-detector diffractometer with graphite monochromatized Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Diffraction data for both complexes were collected by ω scan mode at 298(2) K. Data reduction and cell refinement were performed by the SMART and SAINT programs [17]. Empirical absorption correction was applied by using SADABS [18]. The structures of the complexes were solved by direct methods and refined with the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXL97 package [19]. The non-H atoms in the structures were subjected to refined anisotropic refinement. The amino hydrogen atoms in the complexes were located from difference Fourier maps and refined isotropically, with N-H distances restrained to 0.90(1) Å. The remaining hydrogen atoms were located in geometrically and treated with the riding mode. Crystallographic data and experimental details for the complexes are summarized in Table 1. Selected bond lengths and angles for the complexes are listed in Table 2. Hydrogen bonds are summarized in Table 3.

The molecular structure of the complex 1 is shown in Fig. 1. The complex is an end-to-end thiocyanato-bridged polymeric copper(II) compound, with the Cu···Cu distance of 6.406(1) Å. The asymmetric unit of the complex is [CuL1(NCS)]. The Cu atom is five-coordinated in a square pyramidal coordination. The basal plane of the square pyramid is defined by the phenolate O, imine N and amine N atoms of L1, and one thiocyanate N atom. The apical position of the square pyramid is occupied by one thiocyanate S atom. The Cu1–O1 bond length of 1.879(2) Å in the complex is a little shorter than those [1.91–1.98 Å] reported in similar copper complexes with Schiff bases [16, 20, 21]. The Cu–N bond lengths [1.968(2)–2.014(2) Å] in the complex are comparable to those [1.91–2.05 Å] reported in the copper complexes [16, 20, 21]. The substantial distortion of the square pyramid is revealed by the bond angles between the apical and basal donor atoms, which show deviation from the ideal 90° angle in a regular square pyramid. Atom Cu1 displaced out of the least-squares plane defined by the four basal donor atoms in the direction of the apical position by 0.167(2) Å. The thiocyanate ligands are nearly linear and show bent coordination mode with the Cu atoms (N3–C12–S1/Cu1–N3–C12/Cu1A–S1–C12 = 179.0(3)°/158.2(2)°/116.1(1)°).

Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure Description of 1

The molecular structure of the complex 1 is shown in Fig. 1. The complex is an end-to-end thiocyanato-bridged polymeric copper(II) compound, with the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance of 6.406(1) Å. The asymmetric unit of the complex is [CuL1(NCS)]. The Cu atom is five-coordinated in a square pyramidal coordination. The basal plane of the square pyramid is defined by the phenolate O, imine N and amine N atoms of L1, and one thiocyanate N atom. The apical position of the square pyramid is occupied by one thiocyanate S atom. The Cu1-O1 bond length of 1.879(2) Å in the complex is a little shorter than those [1.91-1.98 Å] reported in similar copper complexes with Schiff bases [16, 20, 21]. The Cu-N bond lengths [1.968(2)-2.014(2) Å] in the complex are comparable to those [1.91-2.05 Å] reported in the copper complexes [16, 20, 21]. The substantial distortion of the square pyramid is revealed by the bond angles between the apical and basal donor atoms, which show deviation from the ideal 90° angle in a regular square pyramid. Atom Cu1 displaced out of the least-squares plane defined by the four basal donor atoms in the direction of the apical position by 0.167(2) Å. The thiocyanate ligands are nearly linear and show bent coordination mode with the Cu atoms (N3-C12-S1/Cu1-N3-C12/Cu1A-S1-C12 = 179.0(3)°/158.2(2)°/116.1(1)°).

elements.content: In the crystal structure of 1, the [CuL1] units are linked through end-to-end thiocyanate bridges, forming chains running along the b axis (Fig. 2). The chains are further linked via intermolecular N–H···S hydrogen bonds in the c direction, forming layers parallel to the bc plane.

elements.content: The molecular structure of the complex 2 is shown in Fig. 3. The complex is an end-on azido-bridged centrosymmetric dimeric copper(II) compound, with the Cu···Cu distance of 3.762(1) Å. The inversion center of the complex is located at the midpoint of the two Cu atoms. The Cu atom is six-coordinated in an octahedral coordination. The equatorial plane of the octahedral geometry is defined by the pyridine N, imine N and amine N atoms of L2, and one azide N atom. The axial positions of the octahedral geometry are occupied by one Br atom and one azide N atom. The Cu1–N1 bond length of 2.036(3) Å in the complex is a little longer than those [1.97–2.02 Å] reported in similar copper complexes with Schiff bases [22, 23]. The remaining Cu–N bond lengths [1.976(3)–2.045(4) Å] in the complex are comparable to those [1.92–2.06 Å] reported in the copper complexes [16, 22, 23]. The substantial distortion of the octahedral coordination is revealed by the coordinate bond angles, which show deviation from the ideal values in a regular octahedral geometry. The axial Cu–Br and Cu–N bonds are much longer than those in the equatorial plane, which is caused by the Jahn–Teller distortion. Atom Cu1 displaced out of the least-squares plane defined by the four equatorial donor atoms in the direction of the Br atom by 0.276(2) Å. The azide ligands are nearly linear and show bent coordination mode with the Cu atoms (N4–N5–N6/Cu1–N4–N5 = 176.2(5)°/132.2(3)°).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Description of 2

The molecular structure of the complex 2 is shown in Fig. 3. The complex is an end-on azido-bridged centrosymmetric dimeric copper(II) compound, with the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance of 3.762(1) Å. The inversion center of the complex is located at the midpoint of the two Cu atoms. The Cu atom is six-coordinated in an octahedral coordination. The equatorial plane of the octahedral geometry is defined by the pyridine N, imine N and amine N atoms of L2, and one azide N atom. The axial positions of the octahedral geometry are occupied by one Br atom and one azide N atom. The Cu1-N1 bond length of 2.036(3) Å in the complex is a little longer than those [1.97-2.02 Å] reported in similar copper complexes with Schiff bases [22, 23]. The remaining Cu-N bond lengths [1.976(3)-2.045(4) Å] in the complex are comparable to those [1.92-2.06 Å] reported in the copper complexes [16, 22, 23]. The substantial distortion of the octahedral coordination is revealed by the coordinate bond angles, which show deviation from the ideal values in a regular octahedral geometry. The axial Cu-Br and Cu-N bonds are much longer than those in the equatorial plane, which is caused by the Jahn-Teller distortion. Atom Cu1 displaced out of the least-squares plane defined by the four equatorial donor atoms in the direction of the Br atom by 0.276(2) Å. The azide ligands are nearly linear and show bent coordination mode with the Cu atoms (N4-N5-N6/Cu1-N4-N5 = 176.2(5)°/132.2(3)°).

elements.content: The weak and broad band centered at 3,412 cm−1 is due to the stretching vibration of the phenolic OH group of HL1. The band is absent in the spectrum of 1 indicating the coordination of the phenolate oxygen atom of the ligand to the Cu atom. The middle and sharp bands indicative of the NH groups are located in the region 3,165–3,230 cm−1 for the Schiff bases and the complexes. The phenolic ν(C–O) in the spectrum of HL1 was observed as strong band at 1,202 cm−1. However, in the spectrum of 1, the band appeared at 1,232 cm−1. This confirms the deprotonation and coordination of the phenolate oxygen atom to the Cu atom. The strong bands at 1,605–1,615 cm−1 in the spectra of the free Schiff bases are due to the azomethine groups, which are shifted toward lower frequencies (1,598 cm−1 for 1 and 1,597 cm−1 for 2), indicating the coordination of azomethine nitrogen atoms to the Cu atoms. The intense band for 1 at 2,097 cm−1 is the typical vibration of the thiocyanate ligands, and that in 2 at 2,053 cm−1 is the typical vibration of the azide ligands. The weak bands in the region 340–600 cm−1 for the complexes are attributed to the Cu–N, Cu–O, Cu–S, and Cu–Br vibrations.
elements.clean_text:
IR Spectra

The weak and broad band centered at 3,412 cm-1 is due to the stretching vibration of the phenolic OH group of HL1. The band is absent in the spectrum of 1 indicating the coordination of the phenolate oxygen atom of the ligand to the Cu atom. The middle and sharp bands indicative of the NH groups are located in the region 3,165-3,230 cm-1 for the Schiff bases and the complexes. The phenolic ν(C-O) in the spectrum of HL1 was observed as strong band at 1,202 cm-1. However, in the spectrum of 1, the band appeared at 1,232 cm-1. This confirms the deprotonation and coordination of the phenolate oxygen atom to the Cu atom. The strong bands at 1,605-1,615 cm-1 in the spectra of the free Schiff bases are due to the azomethine groups, which are shifted toward lower frequencies (1,598 cm-1 for 1 and 1,597 cm-1 for 2), indicating the coordination of azomethine nitrogen atoms to the Cu atoms. The intense band for 1 at 2,097 cm-1 is the typical vibration of the thiocyanate ligands, and that in 2 at 2,053 cm-1 is the typical vibration of the azide ligands. The weak bands in the region 340-600 cm-1 for the complexes are attributed to the Cu-N, Cu-O, Cu-S, and Cu-Br vibrations.

elements.content: A new end-to-end thiocyanato-bridged 1D polymeric copper(II) complex and a new end-on azido-bridged dimeric copper(II) complex have been synthesized and structurally characterized. The Schiff base 2-[1-(2-methylaminoethylimino)ethyl]phenol coordinates to the Cu atom through the phenolate O, imine N, and amine N atoms. The Schiff base N-methyl-N′-(1-pyridin-2-ylethylidene)ethane-1,2-diamine coordinates to the Cu atom through the pyridine N, imine N, and amine N atoms. The pseudohalide anions are versatile bridging groups for the construction of polymeric structures of Schiff base copper(II) complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A new end-to-end thiocyanato-bridged 1D polymeric copper(II) complex and a new end-on azido-bridged dimeric copper(II) complex have been synthesized and structurally characterized. The Schiff base 2-[1-(2-methylaminoethylimino)ethyl]phenol coordinates to the Cu atom through the phenolate O, imine N, and amine N atoms. The Schiff base N-methyl-N'-(1-pyridin-2-ylethylidene)ethane-1,2-diamine coordinates to the Cu atom through the pyridine N, imine N, and amine N atoms. The pseudohalide anions are versatile bridging groups for the construction of polymeric structures of Schiff base copper(II) complexes.

cln_elements.content:
To a stirring methanolic solution (10 mL) containing copper(II) bromide (44.6 mg, 0.2 mmol) was added dropwise a methanolic solution (10 mL) of HL1 (38.4 mg, 0.2 mmol). Then a solution of ammonium thiocyanate (15.2 mg, 0.2 mmol) dissolved in 5 mL water was added to the reaction mixture. The stirring was continued for half an hour and filtered. The filtrate was kept undisturbed at room temperature for a week. Deep blue crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained on slow evaporation of the solvent. Crystals were isolated by filtration and dried in air. Yield 63% with respect to the HL1. Analysis calculated for C12H15CuN3OS: C, 46.1; H, 4.8; N, 13.4%; found: C, 46.3; H, 4.9; N, 13.3%.

Synthesis of [CuBrL<sup>2</sup>(<italic>μ</italic><sub>1,1</sub>-N<sub>3</sub>)]<sub>2</sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

To a stirring methanolic solution (10 mL) containing copper(II) bromide (44.6 mg, 0.2 mmol) was added dropwise a methanolic solution (10 mL) of L2 (35.4 mg, 0.2 mmol). Then a solution of sodium azide (13.0 mg, 0.2 mmol) dissolved in 5 mL water was added to the reaction mixture. The stirring was continued for half an hour and filtered. The filtrate was kept undisturbed at room temperature for a week. Deep blue crystals of 2 suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained on slow evaporation of the solvent. Crystals were isolated by filtration and dried in air. Yield 51% with respect to the L2. Analysis calculated for C20H30Br2Cu2N12: C, 33.1; H, 4.2; N, 23.2%; found: C, 33.0; H, 4.2; N, 23.4%.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [CuL1(μ1,3-NCS)]n (1)

To a stirring methanolic solution (10 mL) containing copper(II) bromide (44.6 mg, 0.2 mmol) was added dropwise a methanolic solution (10 mL) of HL1 (38.4 mg, 0.2 mmol). Then a solution of ammonium thiocyanate (15.2 mg, 0.2 mmol) dissolved in 5 mL water was added to the reaction mixture. The stirring was continued for half an hour and filtered. The filtrate was kept undisturbed at room temperature for a week. Deep blue crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained on slow evaporation of the solvent. Crystals were isolated by filtration and dried in air. Yield 63% with respect to the HL1. Analysis calculated for C12H15CuN3OS: C, 46.1; H, 4.8; N, 13.4%; found: C, 46.3; H, 4.9; N, 13.3%.

Synthesis of [CuBrL2(μ1,1-N3)]2 (2)

To a stirring methanolic solution (10 mL) containing copper(II) bromide (44.6 mg, 0.2 mmol) was added dropwise a methanolic solution (10 mL) of L2 (35.4 mg, 0.2 mmol). Then a solution of sodium azide (13.0 mg, 0.2 mmol) dissolved in 5 mL water was added to the reaction mixture. The stirring was continued for half an hour and filtered. The filtrate was kept undisturbed at room temperature for a week. Deep blue crystals of 2 suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained on slow evaporation of the solvent. Crystals were isolated by filtration and dried in air. Yield 51% with respect to the L2. Analysis calculated for C20H30Br2Cu2N12: C, 33.1; H, 4.2; N, 23.2%; found: C, 33.0; H, 4.2; N, 23.4%.

cln_elements.content: A new end-to-end thiocyanato-bridged 1D polymeric copper(II) complex [CuL1(μ1,3-NCS)]n (1), and a new end-on azido-bridged dimeric copper(II) complex [CuBrL2(μ1,1-N3)]2 (2), where L1 is the deprotonated form of 2-[1-(2-methylaminoethylimino)ethyl]phenol (HL1) and L2 is N-methyl-N′-(1-pyridin-2-ylethylidene)ethane-1,2-diamine, have been synthesized and structurally characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectra, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n with unit cell dimensions a = 10.822(1) Å, b = 10.054(1) Å, c = 12.532(2) Å, β = 106.810(2)°, V = 1305.3(3) Å3, Z = 4, R1 = 0.0341 and wR2 = 0.0766. Complex 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n with unit cell dimensions a = 10.427(2) Å, b = 10.672(2) Å, c = 12.626(2) Å, β = 108.069(9)°, V = 1335.7(4) Å3, Z = 2, R1 = 0.0346 and wR2 = 0.0714. The Cu atom in 1 is in a square pyramidal coordination, and that in 2 is in an octahedral coordination. The Cu···Cu distances are 6.406(1) Å in 1, and 3.762(1) Å in 2. The pseudohalide anions are versatile bridging groups for the construction of polymeric structures of Schiff base copper(II) complexes.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A new end-to-end thiocyanato-bridged 1D polymeric copper(II) complex [CuL1(μ1,3-NCS)]n (1), and a new end-on azido-bridged dimeric copper(II) complex [CuBrL2(μ1,1-N3)]2 (2), where L1 is the deprotonated form of 2-[1-(2-methylaminoethylimino)ethyl]phenol (HL1) and L2 is N-methyl-N'-(1-pyridin-2-ylethylidene)ethane-1,2-diamine, have been synthesized and structurally characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectra, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n with unit cell dimensions a = 10.822(1) Å, b = 10.054(1) Å, c = 12.532(2) Å, β = 106.810(2)°, V = 1305.3(3) Å3, Z = 4, R1 = 0.0341 and wR2 = 0.0766. Complex 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n with unit cell dimensions a = 10.427(2) Å, b = 10.672(2) Å, c = 12.626(2) Å, β = 108.069(9)°, V = 1335.7(4) Å3, Z = 2, R1 = 0.0346 and wR2 = 0.0714. The Cu atom in 1 is in a square pyramidal coordination, and that in 2 is in an octahedral coordination. The Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances are 6.406(1) Å in 1, and 3.762(1) Å in 2. The pseudohalide anions are versatile bridging groups for the construction of polymeric structures of Schiff base copper(II) complexes.

metadata.title: Synthesis and Crystal Structures of Polymeric Copper(II) Complexes Derived from Tridentate Schiff Bases
